verses.text: My son, if you receive my words and store up my commandments within you,
verses.comment: The passage uses a parental instruction motif, showing wisdom is to be treasured and internalized. The language recalls Deut. 6:6-7, pointing to the tradition of hearing, receiving, and obeying teaching.

verses.text: making your ear attentive to wisdom and inclining your heart to understanding,
verses.comment: Receiving wisdom calls for an active choice — ‘making your ear attentive’ recalls the biblical theme of seeking wisdom with one’s whole being (cf. James 1:5).

verses.text: yes, if you call out for insight and lift up your voice for understanding,
verses.comment: True wisdom requires asking and seeking. Jesus echoes these words in Matthew 7:7 (‘Ask, and it will be given to you’), pointing towards the necessity of prayer.

verses.text: if you seek it like silver and search for it as for hidden treasures,
verses.comment: Wisdom is to be pursued with the same urgency as earthly riches. Jesus’ parable of the hidden treasure reflects this same intensity for God’s kingdom.

verses.text: then you will understand the fear of the LORD and find the knowledge of God.
verses.comment: 'Fear of the LORD' is the beginning of wisdom (Prov. 1:7, 9:10). Finding God’s knowledge implies both reverence and relational intimacy, prefiguring the personal knowledge of Christ.

verses.text: For the LORD gives wisdom; from his mouth come knowledge and understanding.
verses.comment: Wisdom is ultimately a divine gift. This phrase mirrors New Testament teaching that true wisdom is found in God and ultimately revealed in Christ (Col. 2:3).

verses.text: He stores up sound wisdom for the upright; he is a shield to those who walk in integrity,
verses.comment: God is portrayed as both the source and protector of wisdom. The theme of God as a shield echoes the motif of trusting in God’s promises and remaining faithful.

verses.text: guarding the paths of justice and preserving the way of his faithful ones.
verses.comment: God safeguards the course of his people, especially those who are faithful. This resonates with the biblical image of the righteous remnant preserved through God’s providence.

verses.text: Then you will understand righteousness and justice and equity—every good path;
verses.comment: Possessing God-given wisdom results in discernment and a life characterized by righteousness, justice, and fairness—key traits also seen in the promised Messiah (Isa. 11:2).

verses.text: for wisdom will enter your heart, and knowledge will be pleasant to your soul;
verses.comment: When wisdom occupies the heart (the center of one’s life), it brings inner delight and transformation—anticipating the interior change spoken of by the prophets (Ez. 36:26-27).

verses.text: discretion will watch over you, understanding will guard you,
verses.comment: The personal qualities of discretion and understanding act as guardians for one’s life. Spiritual discernment is crucial for persevering in faith.

verses.text: delivering you from the way of evil, from men of perverse speech,
verses.comment: Wisdom acts as a protection, keeping the faithful from the influence of the wicked. The idea of ‘perverse speech’ reflects both false teaching and moral corruption.

verses.text: who forsake the paths of uprightness to walk in the ways of darkness,
verses.comment: Turning from uprightness to darkness recalls the imagery used in John 3:19, where people loved darkness rather than light. There’s both a moral and spiritual reality at play.

verses.text: who rejoice in doing evil and delight in the perverseness of the wicked,
verses.comment: The joy of the wicked in their evil is contrasted with the joy of the righteous in truth. Ultimately, the hearts’ delights reveal spiritual allegiances.

verses.text: whose paths are crooked and who are devious in their ways.
verses.comment: Crooked and devious paths point to lives out of alignment with God’s truth. Straight path imagery is frequent in the Bible, culminating in John the Baptist’s call to prepare the way (Luke 3:4-5).

verses.text: So you will be delivered from the forbidden woman, from the adulteress with her smooth words,
verses.comment: The ‘forbidden woman’ is a recurring symbol in Proverbs, representing both literal sexual sin and spiritual unfaithfulness (cf. James 4:4).

verses.text: who forsakes the companion of her youth and forgets the covenant of her God;
verses.comment: ‘Covenant’ language here underscores the seriousness of marital faithfulness reminiscent of God’s covenant with his people. Turning from covenant is both a personal and spiritual tragedy.

verses.text: for her house sinks down to death, and her paths to the departed;
verses.comment: The consequences of her path are ultimately spiritual death—Sheol refers to the realm of the dead.

verses.text: none who go to her come back, nor do they regain the paths of life.
verses.comment: The path of unfaithfulness leads away from life—calling for repentance before it is too late. The exclusivity of this way accentuates the urgency of choosing rightly.

verses.text: So you will walk in the way of the good and keep to the paths of the righteous.
verses.comment: The call is not only to avoid evil but to actively choose and persevere in the way of righteousness, a common theme for perseverance in the faith.

verses.text: For the upright will dwell in the land, and those with integrity will remain in it,
verses.comment: Possessing the land is a symbol of divine blessing. Jesus echoes this in the Beatitudes, promising that the meek will inherit the earth (Matt. 5:5).

verses.text: but the wicked will be cut off from the land, and the treacherous will be uprooted from it.
verses.comment: Being ‘cut off’ is judgment language with eternal consequence—foreshadowing the final separation of the righteous from the wicked seen in Jesus’ teaching (e.g., Matt. 13:41-43).
